message: Please join me in Hollister on August 22nd for a town hall meeting.  Date: Tuesday, August 22, 2017  Time: 6:00-7:30 PM  Location:    Board of Supervisors Chambers County Administration Building 481 4th Street, 1st Floor Hollister, CA 95023                                   For ADA, translation accommodations, and questions,  please contact Congressman Jimmy Panetta’s office at (831) 424-2229. Congressman Jimmy Panetta and Congresswoman Anna Eshoo will hold a joint town hall on Saturday, April 1st at 10:00 a.m.  Moderated by John Laird, California Secretary for Natural Resources.  Date: Saturday, April 1, 2017 Time: 10am-11:30am (doors open at 9:30am) Location: New Brighton Middle School Performing Arts Center, 250 Washburn Ave, Capitola, CA 95010  This event will be streamed on Facebook Live. Earlier today, I was sworn in as a member of the United States House of Representatives and I was thrilled to be accompanied by my wonderful and loving family. Throughout my life, I’ve been devoted to public service and it’s an honor to now serve the Central Coast in Congress. I’m ready to bring fresh energy, independent thinking and a bipartisan collaborative spirit to Washington to move our nation forward and get things done. The Central Coast of California is and always will be my home. I’m very grateful to the voters for allowing me to represent them in Congress and my offices in California and Washington are ready to assist them with any federal issue that may arise.

I’m proud to support the West Coast Ocean Protection Act (H.R. 169). This bill would permanently protect the pristine coast off California, Washington and Oregon from offshore drilling. On the Central Coast, our oceans and coastline are incredibly important for our health, environment and economy. I look forward to continuing to advocate for our oceans and the health of our planet. If you’re interested in learning more about my work to serve you and the Central Coast, please sign up for my e-newsletter: https://panetta.house.gov/contact/newsletter

Here’s another photo from my first day as the Congressman for California’s Central Coast. I’m very honored to serve in Congress and look forward to bringing people together to serve you. To learn more about the Central Coast and my commitment to service, please read this: https://panetta.house.gov/about
Hoping everyone on the Central Coast is OK and safe. Via KSBW TV Action News 8: http://www.ksbw.com/article/another-storm-on-the-way-to-central-coast/8580410

I’m very proud to join many of my colleagues from California to send a letter to Governor Brown to strongly support Congressman Xavier Becerra's appointment as California Attorney General. California has led the nation in many areas and must continue to move forward with innovative solutions that help people and improve people’s lives. As the letter states, “As we prepare for the swearing in of President Donald Trump, California must have an Attorney General who is prepared on day one to protect our environment, stand up for immigrants, and protect the Affordable Care Act.” I couldn’t agree more.

NEWS: Earlier today, I was appointed to the House Agriculture Committee. It’s an honor to serve the Central Coast in Congress and a privilege to join the House Agriculture Committee. Under the leadership of Ranking Member Collin C. Peterson (D-Minn.), I’m looking forward to advocating for specialty crops, organics, animal and plant health, technology to improve sustainability, agriculture research, nutrition and other important issues for Central Coast growers, shippers and farm workers. Growing up in Monterey County and as a recent graduate of Focus Agriculture in Santa Cruz County, I know that our area’s agriculture industry is the economic engine for the Central Coast. The Central Coast produces more than 100 specialty crops, more than any other state and valued at over $5 billion annually, which end up on tables across the nation and world. In addition to advocating for our region’s agriculture industry on the House Agriculture Committee, I’m looking forward to promoting the issues that are important to our rural communities on the Central Coast, including immigration reform and infrastructure and broadband investments.

Please read my column about why the Affordable Care Act (aka Obamacare) is working and why it needs to be repaired, not repealed. Via the Santa Cruz Sentinel: http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/opinion/20170111/rep-jimmy-panetta-we-must-fix-affordable-care-act-not-wipe-out-the-law

Here’s why I want to repair – not repeal – the Affordable Care Act (aka Obamacare). Read it in the Monterey Herald: http://www.montereyherald.com/opinion/20170111/rep-jimmy-panetta-we-must-fix-affordable-care-act-not-wipe-out-the-law

Last night, I offered an amendment and testified in support of it during a House Rules Committee meeting. My amendment would allow people to keep their health care plan if the Affordable Care Act is repealed. My amendment would protect health care for 30 million people nationally, including 5 million Californians and many Central Coast residents. I know the plan isn’t perfect, but the ACA should be improved not abolished. That is why I offered and testified about this. Although the Republican majority blocked my amendment from moving to the House Floor for a vote, I will continue working to repair the ACA, not repeal it. Read my full statement here: https://panetta.house.gov/media/press-releases/panetta-testifies-his-amendment-protect-health-care-millions

This morning, I organized a Health Care Leadership Roundtable. I’d like to thank the representatives from patient advocacy groups and health care professionals from local hospitals and clinics for attending and for sharing their concerns about repealing the Affordable Care Act and their ideas on ways to repair the plan. I know the ACA isn’t perfect, but it should be improved not abolished. To learn more about the ACA and my views on the health care plan, please read  my opinion piece in the Monterey Herald: http://www.montereyherald.com/opinion/20170111/rep-jimmy-panetta-we-must-fix-affordable-care-act-not-wipe-out-the-law

Today, I had the honor and pleasure to celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in Seaside. His words still ring true today: “Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that.” #MLKDay

A few days ago, I had the pleasure and honor to meet Chief of Naval Operations Adm. John Richardson. It was great to meet him and I promoted Naval Postgraduate School and our other U.S. Navy assets on the Central Coast.

On Saturday, January 21, I’m planning to meet some Central Coast constituents who are in town to voice their opinions on health care, equality, and our environment. We’re going to meet at 9:45am in front of the main entrance to the U.S. Botanic Garden. If you are in Washington, DC and would like to join us, please meet us there!

Proud to announce that I have joined both the Congressional Pro-Choice Caucus and Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus. These issues reflect our basic civil liberties and I’m ready to get to work pushing for equality, social justice, improved access to health care, and policies and programs to support healthy families. I look forward to bringing people together to move our nation forward. https://panetta.house.gov/media/press-releases/panetta-joins-pro-choice-lgbt-caucuses

This week, I had the honor and pleasure to travel across the Central Coast meeting with constituents, organizations, and community leaders. I wanted to make sure that I took every opportunity to hear about the issues that matter most to you. I met with representatives from patient advocacy groups and health care professionals from local hospitals and clinics to hear about repairing - not repealing - the Affordable Care Act, toured Salud Para La Gente, marched in the MLK Day Parade in Seaside, supported Planned Parenthood at a luncheon, met with members of the Democratic Women of Monterey County, checked levees at the Pajaro River, and sat down with leaders from the Naval Postgraduate School.

Today, a letter I signed was sent to Donald Trump about protecting health care for women and girls. The letter says: “We urge you to reject a policy agenda that would harm women, starting with your efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act and defund Planned Parenthood.” I disagree with Donald Trump on many levels and will stand up for Central Coast priorities. As a proud member of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus and Pro-Choice Caucus, I will continue to advocate for women’s health, improved access to health care, and policies and programs to support healthy families.

Today, students from Salinas’ Dream Academy and Watsonville’s St. Francis High School visited my DC office to learn more about how I serve the Central Coast. I loved hearing their thoughtful questions, and was inspired by their drive and patriotism. I look forward to spending more time with many of these students this Saturday in Washington as we voice our concerns for our environment, DREAMers, health care, equality, and more.

Today, Donald Trump was sworn in as the 45th President of the United States. Instead of offering to bring the nation together, his speech was filled with rhetoric echoing his divisive campaign. I respect the office of the presidency but I understand that the next four years will bring challenges. I stand ready to face those challenges and ready to defend the rights of all my constituents by fighting any harmful policies put forward by the Republican majority in Congress and the Trump Administration. I will not compromise on the core values we hold dear on the Central Coast, but if there are opportunities to work across the aisle, I will look to bring people together to move forward on innovative solutions that best serve our communities and nation. I am honored to represent everyone from California’s 20th Congressional District, which includes voters across the political spectrum. As your Congressman, I will always fight for the best interests of the Central Coast and our country.

Thrilled to join Central Coast students and constituents in Washington DC today to voice our concerns about health care, our environment, equality, women's rights and more! This is why we show up, this is why we fight. Onward.
Exactly. Let's protect one another. In DC at the  Women's March.

Today, I was joined by many students and residents from the Central Coast for the Women's March On Washington and it was moving, uplifting and inspiring. For anyone who joined marches across the nation and the Central Coast, even though I was marching in Washington DC, I was with you in spirit.

On January 22, 1973, the Supreme Court ruled in Roe v Wade that the constitutional right to privacy extends to a woman’s right to make her own personal medical decisions. 44 years later, there's an empty seat on the Supreme Court which will be filled by President Trump and there's also a Republican majority in Congress already moving to change our health care system and send us backwards, not forwards. That stakes are too high to simply do nothing. That's why I joined many Central Coast residents yesterday for the Women's March on Washington and that's why I'm proud to join the Congressional Pro Choice Caucus to stand up and fight for the progress we've made. I’m ready to get to work pushing for equality, social justice, improved access to health care, and policies and programs to support healthy families.

I was thrilled and honored to join many Central Coast residents and students on the National Mall and Memorial Parks on Saturday for the Women’s March on Washington. Please check out these photos!

Today, I stood in front of my colleagues on the House Floor for the first time and spoke about protecting the most vulnerable in my district and across our nation. Reproductive health care and family planning services are essential for many families across the nation and especially on the Central Coast. Watch my full statement here:

I’ve heard from many constituents on the Central Coast expressing their views on President Trump’s recent actions.   First – even though I don’t get a vote on President Trump’s cabinet appointees (only Senators get to vote on cabinet picks), I have major concerns with his appointees’ public statements on environmental, social, and economic issues. Rest assured that I will fight for the progress we’ve made as a country these last eight years.   Second – I vehemently disagree with President Trump on many levels and believe his campaign was filled with divisive rhetoric, a tone that he’s carried with him into the White House.   Third – I firmly believe that diversity within the Central Coast and nation must be valued, not belittled. To put that into action, I am pleased to share that I joined the LGBT Caucus which pushes for equality and social justice for the LGBT community, and the Pro Choice Caucus to advocate for policies that advance the reproductive health care needs of women.   Fourth – I believe the Affordable Care Act (aka Obamacare) should be repaired, not repealed, and I oppose efforts to defund Planned Parenthood. Additionally, in my very first floor speech as a Congressman, I urged my colleagues to protect health care for women.   Fifth – as the grandson of immigrants who realized the American dream of freedom, prosperity, and equality, I am extremely disappointed by President Trump’s decision today to sign anti-immigrant executive orders. I firmly believe that diversity within our country must be valued, not belittled. President Trump’s orders do not reflect our Central Coast values of inclusivity, equality, and striving for the American dream, and now thousands of hardworking immigrants in our communities may bear the brunt of this destructive policy. I will continue to advocate for bipartisan comprehensive immigration reform, champion the current protections afforded to DREAMers in our community, and oppose any efforts to repeal DACA. Read my full statement about President Trump’s anti-immigrant orders here: https://panetta.house.gov/media/press-releases/panetta-statement-president-trump-s-anti-immigrant-executive-orders

Today, I toured the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Agricultural Resource Service Station in Salinas, led by Jim McCreight. Our tour highlighted the critical role that the station plays in research for our vibrant agriculture community. We discussed a wide range of topics, including research on pesticide resistance and disease resistance, and how industry experts are working to increase the nutritional value of food. The station also provides a learning center for students from both Hartnell College and the UC system to conduct research that is applicable to California agriculture. As a 2015 graduate of the Focus Agriculture program in Santa Cruz County, I had a blast touring the facility and learning even more about the number one economic engine in our region. Back in Washington, I will continue to advocate for our Central Coast agriculture industry.

People around the world look to the United States as a beacon of hope and freedom through its enlightened and bold leadership. This past week, disappointedly and disturbingly, our executive branch did a disservice to our nation's fundamental values by making disgraceful decisions based on intolerance, racism, and fear. That type of insular reaction is contrary to the historical responsibilities of our nation to welcome those fleeing terror and persecution.    When my grandparents came to this country to attain the American Dream, they were welcomed by the Statue of Liberty. The text at the base of that beacon reads, 'Give me your tired, your poor, Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free.’ We must never forget that being American means that we bear the burden to serve one another and welcome people of all religions and nationalities who are willing to come here and share in that responsibility. President Trump’s executive actions are not reflective of our values. As a nation of immigrants, we are stronger because of our diversity, and when we come together in the name of inclusivity and equality, our voices cannot be silenced.

Over the last week, I delivered my first remarks on the House Floor as your Congressman by urging my colleagues to stand up for women’s health care. I then flew home and saw first-hand the flood damage in San Benito County, met with Jeff Cattaneo to be briefed on the San Justo Reservoir zebra mussel problem, toured the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Agricultural Resource Service Station in Salinas, met with Indivisible Santa Cruz, and visited Jacob's Heart Children's Cancer Support Services in Watsonville to discuss the importance of coordinating care for children with complex medical needs and providing "whole child" care to children and their families. I also visited Dientes Community Dental Care and Dominican Hospital to continue hearing about potential impacts of repealing the Affordable Care Act. I’m honored to serve you in Congress and look forward to hearing more about the issues that matter most to you.

Today, I signed on to my colleague Representative Zoe Lofgren’s legislation called the Statue of Liberty Values Act of 2017 (SOLVE). This important bill would make President Trump’s most recent executive order to shut out people from several Muslim nations and end the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program “null and void, shall have no force and effect, and may not be implemented, administered, enforced, or carried out.”   Over the last two weeks, President Trump has signed several executive orders to further his agenda of hate, discrimination, bigotry, and division. I have received many calls, emails, and letters from Central Coast residents and I stand with you – President Trump’s anti-Muslim and anti-immigrant executive actions are attacks on the foundation of our American democracy and do nothing to promote our national security.   When my grandparents came to this country to attain the American Dream, they were welcomed by the Statue of Liberty. As a nation of immigrants, we are stronger because of our diversity, and when we come together in the name of inclusivity and equality, our voices cannot be silenced.
This evening, I joined my Democratic colleagues on the steps of the Supreme Court to stand against President Trump’s anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim executive orders.

President Trump fired Acting Attorney General Sally Yates for upholding the Constitution of the United States. Yates rightfully refused to defend his unconstitutional executive order closing our nation's borders to people from several predominately Muslim-majority countries and ending the refugee resettlement program. On the Central Coast, immigrants and immigrant families are a critical part of our diverse and vibrant community. As a former deputy district attorney, I know firsthand the responsibility that our justice system has to protect the most vulnerable. President Trump should get used to federal employees, and American citizens alike, calling out his indefensible, ill-conceived, and intolerant orders. We will not be silent.

Today, I signed a letter to the U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) requesting an immediate review and report to Congress on the circumstances surrounding Trump's executive order that suspended refugee admissions and restricted the flow of immigrants from Muslim nations to the United States. Central Coast residents want answers – we’re going to get them.

Today marks the start of Black History Month, a time for us to reflect on the countless contributions that African Americans have made to this nation and continue to make every day. On the Central Coast, we’re blessed to live within a vibrant and diverse community. In fact, Fort Ord was the first military base in the nation to be desegregated. I hope you’ll join with me to fight for equality, social justice, and improved policies and programs to support minority communities – not just this month, but every day.
NA

Had a great time this morning speaking at the Food Tank: The Food Think Tank Summit in DC. Our Central Coast growers, shippers, and farm workers provide our nation with some of the most nutritious goods out there. We fill the shelves in your grocery stores, the cup at your juice bar, and the salad bars at your kids’ schools. I look forward to advocating for providing our agriculture industry with critical research investments that expand access to safe and nutritious fruits and vegetables. When we invest in agriculture, we’re investing in the health of our families.

Today, I stood in front of my colleagues on the House Floor to speak out against President Trump’s Muslim ban. His executive order not only makes us unsafe, it goes against our fundamental values. If people are willing to take risks to live the American Dream, we don’t stop them. We welcome them. Watch my full remarks here:
I shared my thoughts on President Trump's anti-immigrant executive orders in this weekend's paper. Read here:

Enjoyed meeting with the San Benito Chapter of LULAC in Hollister on Saturday. I heard their concerns about President Trump's recent executive orders regarding immigrants and refugees, and I will carry their voices to my colleagues in Washington. Rest assured, I will continue to speak out against the president's intolerant orders and advocate for all members of our diverse community.

Enjoyed meeting with the California Farm Bureau Federation today. I have the honor of representing one of the most bountiful districts in the nation – the Salad Bowl of the World. I will continue to advocate for specialty crops, innovative technology, research opportunities, organic production, animal and plant health, and nutrition. I will also continue to promote issues that are important to our agriculture industry, including immigration reform and investments in infrastructure and broadband.

President Trump's anti-immigration orders make our country less safe. We are a nation of immigrants, and we are stronger because of our diversity.   I spoke on the House Floor today to share my family's immigration story, and to carry the concerned voices of my constituents to my colleagues in Washington.
Had a great discussion this morning with Philippe Cousteau and Ashlan Gorse Cousteau about climate change & how we must fight to protect our oceans.

Join us for a town hall at Hartnell College on Sunday, February 12, 2017 at 1:00 p.m.  Congressman Panetta will be joined by Representative Zoe Lofgren and other federal & local officials to hear Central Coast residents' concerns regarding President Trump’s executive orders on immigration.   During the town hall, community members will also obtain “Know Your Rights” information from legal experts.  ---  Acompáñenos para una asamblea pública en el Colegio Comunitario de Hartnell el domingo, 12 de febrero de 2017 a la 1:00 p.m.  El Congresista Panetta será acompañado por la Representante Zoe Lofgren y otros funcionarios locales y federales para escuchar las preocupaciones de los residentes de Central Coast sobre las ordenes ejecutivas ante inmigración del Presidente Trump.   Durante la asamblea pública, expertos legales compartirán información acerca de los derechos de la comunidad.

I am pleased that a federal appeals court refused to reinstate President Donald Trump’s travel ban on refugees from certain countries.  Our system of checks and balances worked and reaffirmed our nation’s values of inclusiveness and acceptance, no matter who you are, who you pray to, or what you look like.  Rest assured, I will continue to speak out against discriminatory and unconstitutional actions.

Thank you to all who made it to the immigration town hall this afternoon.  At a time when many in our community are fearful and uncertain about their future, it was inspiring to see so many people come together in support of each other. To our immigrant neighbors and friends, I will reiterate what I said at the beginning of the town hall: You are not alone. No estas solo.  This town hall was an excellent opportunity for me to hear directly from Central Coast community members. I will take what you shared with me back to Washington and keep fighting for all members of our diverse community.   For those who didn’t have a chance to attend today’s town hall, I am hoping to host other events in the district soon. It is very important to me to continue to be available to hear your concerns and questions, so please contact my office any time.   Special thanks to Representative Zoe Lofgren, Salinas Police Chief Adele Fresé, the American Immigration Lawyers Association, Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey, Michael Mehr, Hartnell College President Dr. Willard Lewallen, and moderator Erica Padilla-Chavez for their participation.

Due to this morning’s U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operation in Santa Cruz County, I am working with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and local law enforcement to get further information about the operations that were conducted. I will continue to press DHS and ICE for more details about the operations and I will provide updates as soon as possible.

Early yesterday morning and unbeknownst to many, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Santa Cruz Police Department conducted an arrest operation in Santa Cruz County. That law enforcement action led to the arrest of several gang members who have committed serious and violent felonies in the local area. The operation capped a five-year covert investigation into a violent criminal street gang and, according to law enforcement officials, was not focused on violations of immigration laws.  While I agree with federal law enforcement actions that target violent criminals and enhance our public safety, I will be requesting greater transparency and clarity from DHS when it comes to the execution of these types of raids in our communities. Currently, there is a great amount of uncertainty and fear in our immigrant community. That feeling is understandable considering the recent events, including the Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agency (ICE) raids that were executed last week across the nation. Although those raids apparently were planned during the Obama administration, that Administration made clear its priorities for removal, which included convicted criminals and individuals who posed a threat to public safety, border security, and national security. The Trump administration’s priorities on immigration are not clear due to the recent Executive Order on deportation, that could be interpreted to apply to every undocumented individual present within our borders.    I will continue to demand communication and clarity from DHS and ICE, and I will be meeting with representatives of those agencies. As I discussed during my immigration town hall on Sunday in Salinas, however, it is important to be prepared and know your rights when it comes to immigration enforcement procedures. Please know that you are not alone and that my office will try to be a resource on immigration in any way possible.

I had a productive conversation today with fellow members of the Agriculture Subcommittee on Biotechnology, Horticulture, and Research. We discussed how we can best ensure farm workers’ health and safety while also working to provide growers with the tools necessary to produce the fresh fruits and vegetables that are so critical to the economy of California’s central coast.

Today, I stood in front of my colleagues on the House Floor to discuss my Commitment to Civility. I believe that this commitment that we have made to each other, our communities, and our country will lead to our constituents' confidence not just in Congress but in our democracy.
Congress should be promoting, protecting, and preserving access to family planning services. View my remarks on the House floor here:

I am pleased that FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency quickly approved California’s request for federal assistance. Monterey, San Benito, Santa Clara, and Santa Cruz Counties were all impacted by the flooding that took place in January, and this federal aid will provide much needed resources to our district. I will monitor the ongoing recovery efforts, and continue to support our affected communities in any way I can.

The Salinas valley has long dealt with challenging labor shortages. Today at a House Agriculture Committee hearing, I was able to address this issue with an official from the U.S. Department of Agriculture and get his feedback about how to solve this problem. I will follow up with USDA and other agencies, and continue to work to meet the needs of our agriculture industry.
Had the chance to join my colleague, Rep. Dan Newhouse, and United Fresh Produce Association this morning to talk about the challenges faced by specialty crop growers.
Enjoyed meeting with LULAC today to discuss immigration, health care, and public service.

Today during the House Agriculture Committee's hearing on SNAP choice, I asked the witnesses about ways we can incentivize healthy food choices and expand programs that help facilitate those purchases. I look forward to continuing these discussions and advocating for increased access to the nutritious specialty crops produced on the Central Coast.

Saddened to hear about the passing of Former Leader Robert Michel. He was a good example of a public servant who understood what it took to get things done in Washington, D.C.  I was honored to travel with Leader Michel and Democratic Speaker Tom Foley to Japan back in 1989.  During that trip, I observed not only respect and admiration between the two gentlemen, but a tried and true friendship.  Their personal relationship clearly was the foundation for the bipartisan work they accomplished.  Congress can learn a thing or two from his example, I know I did.  My thoughts are with his family.

Toured some of the winter storm damage in Santa Cruz today. I will continue to monitor the ongoing recovery efforts along the Central Coast, and support our affected communities in any way that I can.

Today I met with Defense Language Institute Foreign Language Center's students, faculty, staff, and military cadre. Professional military education is an important part of military readiness and training, and should be valued as such. I will continue to advocate for Team Monterey and the importance of including professional education in military training.

Today, President Trump rescinded U.S. Departments of Education and Justice joint guidance providing support and security to transgender students. This decision is cruel.  We should be working to ensure equality and dignity for the transgender community, not marginalizing them through discriminatory and harmful policies. I will continue to advocate for all members of the LGBT community here in Congress and as a member of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus.

I am disturbed by ICE’s conduct during their February 13th operation in Santa Cruz. I stand with our local Santa Cruz Police Department (SCPD) and Chief Kevin Vogel, and will continue to work with them to demand complete information from ICE about the scope of the operation.   I am in touch with federal immigration agencies. I called ICE on February 13th, and have followed up with DHS multiple times demanding information and transparency.  Members of our community should not live in fear that they may be detained or deported, or that their children may be separated from them, because of who they know or where they live.   What’s worse, the breakdown in trust between ICE and SCPD puts our communities at risk. People in our community are already rightfully fearful due to the administration’s recent anti-immigrant executive orders and directives. SCPD has a very successful community policing record, and works every day to retain trust between immigrant communities and local law enforcement because doing so is paramount in keeping our neighborhoods safe. ICE has violated and betrayed that trust.  I will continue to demand communication, clarity, and transparency from DHS and ICE, and I am working with my colleagues on the House Appropriations Homeland Security Subcommittee to hold ICE accountable for their actions.

During this past recess week, I had the opportunity to meet with a lot of really incredible constituents.  First, I spent the majority of the week working to help our communities impacted by the back to back storm surges. Our towns have hardly had time to recover from the January storms before being pummeled again over the holiday weekend. I was able to tour the damage in Santa Cruz and Big Sur, as well as other communities across the region. I spoke with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to advocate for our communities and to better understand how they are coordinating with CalOES to address the needs of those affected. We have received a presidential disaster declaration for the storms that occurred from January 3-12, and assessments on damage caused by following storms is ongoing. I will continue to monitor these assessments and push for federal resources to provide assistance.   I spoke with UC Santa Cruz students about how DACA has helped them succeed. I sat down with senior citizens in Santa Cruz to discuss protecting our health care, then with Santa Cruz for Bernie to discuss local issues. The DCMP Democratic Club of the Monterey Peninsula and I discussed ways we could continue to fight for Democratic priorities at home and in Washington.  On Wednesday, I spent the day at the Defense Language Institute Foreign Language Center meeting with students, faculty, staff, and military cadre. I spent the following day at Fort Hunter Liggett, touring the facilities for the first time since taking office. There, I participated in a ribbon cutting ceremony for their newly dedicated athletic field and Operational Readiness Training Complex. It was a humbling experience, being surrounded once again by the brave military men and women who serve our country.   Later in the week, I sat down with the Monterey County Farm Bureau to discuss agriculture and farm bill priorities, and participated in a California Department of Food & Agriculture listening session to hear from producers in our district. Alongside California Secretary of Agriculture Karen Ross, I heard feedback from the growers and shippers of the central coast to help me get a better understanding of the challenges they face in their business, how current programs function, and improvements they would like to see as my committee negotiates the next farm bill.  I also spoke with the NRDC (Natural Resources Defense Council) about protecting our environment. I then discussed the importance of public investment in protecting and preserving our region’s natural beauty and public lands at the Sustainable Hospitality Development Symposium in Monterey.

As a veteran, I understand that service doesn’t stop once you take off your uniform. Today, I met with a group of gentlemen who perfectly exemplify that sentiment, the Disabled American Veterans (and their "intern"). Our military men and women make sacrifices every day to keep our country safe and secure. I will continue to fight to make sure that they get the support they need not only on the battlefield, but also when they return home.

Today, I testified in front of my colleagues on the House Appropriations Committee about supporting programs that protect marine sanctuaries and sustaining federal investment in fire breaks.  I have seen first-hand the incredible, positive impact National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) programs have on our country – most recently as a former member of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary Advisory Council, and when I worked on a NOAA ship conducting oceanographic research off the coast of Alaska. Maintaining funds for NOAA programs that protect our natural resources and educate the public are critical for our environment, recreation, tourism, university science programs, marine-research institutions, and our $2.8 billion ocean-related economy.   I have also seen first-hand the incredible destruction caused by wildfires. Clearly, funds for fighting fires are vital to our communities, but just as important are funds for preventing fires. We must recognize that sustained government investment in fire prevention, like federally established fire breaks, are imperative in keeping our communities safe.   I grew up on the Central Coast. I believe that having our district’s parks, monuments, and marine sanctuary in my backyard during my formative years made me who I am today. I want my daughters to have the same positive and irreplaceable experiences that I had, and that starts with advocating for the funding of programs that are vital to the preservation and protection of our natural resources.

Last night, President Trump delivered his first speech before a joint session of Congress.  Although he was measured in his tone, the President maintained the same divisive and dangerous message he used throughout his campaign.  Click here to read my full statement.

During his first speech before a joint session of Congress, President Trump doubled down on his divisive and dangerous rhetoric against immigrants.  So today, I stood in front of my colleagues on the House Floor and invited President Trump to visit our district to see first-hand how immigrants contribute to our community.

Education is the incubator of American innovation, prosperity, and economic equality. Today, I testified in front of my colleagues on the House Appropriations Committee about the need for funding education programs, which build the foundation of success for future generations.

During Women’s History Month, we recognize and honor the contributions women have made to our country. We also renew our commitment to fight for women’s rights and consider the opportunities that still remain.   Ultimately, the challenges and burdens women face are shared by all Americans. Today, I joined my Democratic colleagues in the House in introducing a bill to that would provide an opportunity for agricultural workers to apply for legal status.   The bill would create a program that would allow agricultural workers and their families to apply for a “Blue Card” that gives them legal status and work authorization if they show consistent employment in U.S. agriculture over the past two years, pay a fine, and pass a thorough background check.  A 3- to 5- year path to citizenship is provided to those who continue to work in agriculture for the requisite amount of time.  Immigrant farmworkers are not only the backbone of our nation’s agriculture industry, they and their families are the heart and soul of many rural communities. Spoke at the Capitol Hill Ocean Week conference today. I spoke about how growing up on the central coast of California instilled in me a sense of responsibility - to protect our pristine coastlines, our marine sanctuary, our environment, and our ocean.   This weekend, my daughter, Gia, and I watched a marine mammal release in Monterey. She couldn’t stop smiling and giggling when she saw the five seals splash around in the water. She’ll never forget that moment, and I’ll never forget her laughter.  Over the last six months, the administration has taken some steps that will make it harder to protect our environment and oceans. From shrinking our responsibilities in international treaties dealing with climate change, to signing an executive order with the goal of finding mineral and energy potential in our National Marine Sanctuaries and National Monuments, to signing a "Proclamation for National Ocean Month” that in my opinion is more of a doctrine for oil exploration.   I’m not sitting back while all of this is happening. Every day, my colleagues in Congress and I are fighting this administration when it comes to protecting our oceans. Because we believe that when we protect our oceans, we protect our security. Our national security, when it comes to sea level rise affecting not only our coastal communities, but our military bases. Our food security, when it comes to solving ocean acidification and researching aquaculture. Our environmental security, when it comes to keeping our oceans, sanctuaries, and monuments free from oil spills and plastics.  We can’t do it alone, we need innovative leaders to think outside of the box and help us fight to protect our environment. But we have to act. I hope that our legacies will be reflected in the laughter of children when they experience the joys of our oceans. We cannot give up.

I joined my colleagues in the House and Senate in writing a letter urging U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross to extend the public comment period for Marine Sanctuaries targeted under Executive Order 13795, Implementing an America-First Offshore Energy Strategy.  It takes time and thought to respond effectively to this request to review a number of federal actions spanning a decade and impacting hundreds of millions of acres.  Protecting and preserving our treasured resources drives the local economies in many communities, and residents should have sufficient time to provide input and voice concerns about possible changes resulting from this review.  We wrote, in part, to Secretary Ross:  "While we recognize that the terms of the Executive Order require that the Department report to the White House by October 25, 2017, meaningful public participation will require a comment period longer than thirty days. Furthermore, the Order specifically requests comment on the adequacy of Federal, State, and tribal consultations conducted prior to the eleven designations or expansions.  Extending the comment period would give these same entities a better opportunity to provide critical input as part of this review. Public input and community engagement are hallmarks of the National Marine Sanctuaries program, and such a short public comment period is inconsistent with the processes that created and expanded the affected sanctuaries. We strongly urge you to extend the public comment period to at least ninety days."

Congress has failed to pass any immigration reform since 1986. That inaction has created a lot of uncertainty for our agriculture industry and the hardworking people who feed our families. Our communities are relying on us to act. That’s why I’ve joined my colleagues in the House to cosponsor the Agricultural Worker Program Act, also known as the Blue Card bill.  This bill, which was a provision within of the Senate’s 2013 bipartisan immigration reform bill, would help address the current labor shortage facing producers throughout the central coast of California. This bill limits the pool of undocumented immigrants to workers who can prove employment in the U.S. agricultural industry for at least 100 work day over the last two years after enactment. The bill also requires participants to prove employment in U.S. agriculture for at least 100 days per year over the next 5 years to adjust their status to permanent residency.  The Blue Card bill is one part of a larger conversation about reforming our broken immigration system. This bill will help ensure the people who live, work, and contribute in California can step out of the shadows and continue to move our economy forward. Happening now- I'm holding a #ProtectDreamers press conference and roundtable for DACA recipients at Hartnell College.

Today, I held a roundtable at Hartnell College with thirty Dreamers, who are currently enrolled in the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. The young people, brought to the United States as children, enrolled in DACA to be protected from deportation and to earn their citizenship. I arranged the roundtable in response to President Donald Trump’s announcement on Tuesday that he would terminate the DACA program, calling on Congress to consider legislative solutions.    The Dreamers I met with told me about their families, their lives, and their hard work to be a part of and positively contribute to our community. Their parents took great risks to bring them here to give them a better life. These young men and women are well aware of their obligation to give back to the country that gave them so much opportunity. In order to fulfill that responsibility, each Dreamer works hard to succeed in school, at work, for their families and our community. Now, they are threatened with potentially being forced to leave the only country that they are so proud to call home. Democrats and Republicans in Congress must work together to pass legislation that provides Dreamers throughout our community and country the opportunity to fulfill the American Dream.   At the roundtable, I took the Dreamers’ questions, listened to how the DACA program has positively impacted their lives, and heard their concerns about the end of the program as it stands. I also discussed my efforts to protect Dreamers, sharing that I am working to pass legislation that would ensure permanent resident status to DACA recipients and others working to become citizens. California is home to 1 in 4 of the nation’s total DACA population, and an estimated 20,000 Dreamers currently live in California’s 20th congressional district. I will take what he learned back to Washington to share with my colleagues in Congress as we debate long-term solutions.     Prior to the roundtable, I held a press conference, where he and two Dreamers currently enrolled at Hartnell College highlighted the contributions Dreamers make to our economy, our communities, and our country.

This week, I cosponsored the Federal Perkins Loan Program Extension Act of 2017, HR 2482. The Perkins Loan program is scheduled to expire on September 30, 2017 if Congress does not act to reauthorize this program. This bipartisan legislation would extend the program for a period of two years.   The Federal Perkins Loan Program is a popular and effective financial aid program currently utilized by over 500,000 students nationwide. Perkins Loans borrowers are predominantly from lower income families and are often the first in their family to attend college. Unlike many other student loan programs, Perkins is administered directly by colleges and universities who originate the loans, counsel their students through repayment, and select contractors for servicing and collection.  I am proud to cosponsor this bill, and will continue to advocate for affordable education options for students and their families.

Had a productive meeting with an immigration working group composed of local non-profit organizations. We discussed, among other topics, what Congress is doing for DACA recipients.   There are a number of bills related to DACA being debated by members of Congress. I’ll highlight three. The BRIDGE Act, the Bar Removal of Individuals who Dream and Grow Economy, is the congressional equivalent to DACA. If passed, it would give a three year extension of the DACA program. While I support the BRIDGE Act, I do not think that Congress can stop there, because it is merely a temporary fix to keep Dreamers in this country. The second, the RAC Act, Recognizing America’s Children Act, meets the requirements of DACA and provides conditional protected status for ten years, and establishes certain eligibility requirements. The third, the DREAM Act, of which I am a cosponsor, is a pathway to citizenship for students to have a chance to earn legal status if they came here as children, are long-term U.S. residents, have good moral character, and complete two years of college or military service in good standing.  The reality is that in order to vote on any of these bills, the majority’s leadership needs to bring these pieces of legislation to the floor of the House of Representatives. We need to make sure that the majority understands the importance of passing long-lasting legislation to ensure that DREAMers can continue to give back to our country. As a former prosecutor, I know the importance of evidence when making a case. That is why I held a press conference at Hartnell College, where two young women shared their stories about how DACA has positively impacted their lives, and held a roundtable with thirty Dreamers to learn more about their experiences. It is also why I wanted to meet with this working group. They are doing a great job for our local immigrant community. I am thankful for our discussion.

Today, I introduced bipartisan legislation with my colleague, Rep. Carlos Curbelo (R-FL-26), to make federally funded infrastructure more resilient to flooding.   Flooding is the most common weather-related event, occurring in 90 percent of natural disasters in the United States. Federal flood-related disasters have cost American taxpayers approximately $51 billion between 2005 and May 2017 in FEMA Public Assistance spending alone. According to the National Institute for Building Sciences, every dollar invested in mitigation results in $4 saved in recovery costs. Making the proper investments now to prevent the higher costs of flooding in the future represents sound, fiscally responsible public policy.    We on the central coast of California well understand the impact that flooding has on our region. As we have seen with the recent storms in Texas, Florida, Louisiana, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands, the risk of severe flooding is a reality for communities across the country.   Congress is preparing to make historic investments to rebuild communities devastated by recent hurricanes, and working to reauthorize the National Flood Insurance Program, so it is critical that flood mitigation policies are adopted for federal infrastructure projects. Today, I spoke in support of the bipartisan Gold Star Family Support and Installation Access Act of 2017, of which I am an original cosponsor.  The Gold Star Family Support Act would require the Secretary of Defense to issue common installation access cards to Gold Star spouses and dependent children for life. These cards will allow families to attend memorial events, visit gravesites, and access benefits for which they are already entitled. It would also extend on-base commissary, exchange, and MWR facilities access for all surviving spouses, regardless of remarriage, who have dependent children of the deceased service member under their guardianship. Current Department of Defense policy rescinds on-base benefits to surviving spouses of deceased service members who remarry, even when there are dependent children under guardianship of surviving spouse who remain eligible for benefits, effectively rendering these benefits inaccessible by the children of the deceased member.     Since World War I, the gold star symbol has been used by American families to honor members of the Armed Forces who have given their lives in service to the nation. Currently, the only Gold Star benefit currently defined in law is a lapel pin. This bill would change that.

This is an incredible discovery that sheds more light on gravitational waves. Huge congratulations to local UC Santa Cruz assistant professor of astronomy and astrophysics Ryan Foley and his team!   "For the first time, two neutron stars in a nearby galaxy have been observed engaging in a spiral death dance around one another until they collided. What resulted from that collision is being called an "unprecedented" discovery that is ushering in a new era of astronomy, scientists announced Monday. In a collaboration with UC Santa Cruz, Carnegie Observatories were the first in the world to discover this event. They were able to collect early data just before, during and after the collision and study it in more detail. The discovery confirms that gamma-ray bursts can result from the collision of neutron stars, as well as that heavy elements are created as a result of violent collisions between stars. It confirms what these neutron stars look like when they collide. And it confirms that gravitational waves and light can happen together."

State and federal recovery officials urge California residents to watch for and report any suspicious activity or potential fraud from scam artists, identity thieves and other criminals who may try to prey on vulnerable survivors of the October wildfires.  Common post-disaster fraud practices include:  • Fake offers of state or federal aid:  o Beware if anyone claiming to be from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) or the state visits, calls or emails asking for an applicant’s Social Security number, bank account number or other sensitive information.  o Avoid scam artists who promise a disaster grant and ask for cash deposits or advance payments in full.  o Know that federal workers do not solicit or accept money. FEMA and the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) staff never charge applicants for disaster assistance, inspections or help in filling out applications. Do not give out information and report people claiming to be government workers to local police.  o Provide your Social Security number and banking information only when registering for FEMA assistance, either by calling 800-621-3362, TTY 800-462-7585, or going online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov or the smart phone FEMA App. If you use 711-Relay or Video Relay Services, call 800-621-3362. Operators are multilingual and calls are answered from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. seven days a week.   • Phony housing inspectors: Owners/applicants may be especially vulnerable to phony housing inspectors claiming to represent FEMA or SBA. An applicant should always:  o Ask to see the inspector’s identification badge. All federal employees and contractors carry official, laminated photo identification.  o Inspectors also have each applicant’s nine-digit registration number.  o FEMA inspectors never require banking information.  It is important to note that FEMA housing inspectors verify damage, but do not hire or endorse specific contractors to fix homes or recommend repairs.  They do not determine your eligibility for assistance.   • Fraudulent building contractors: When hiring a contractor, be sure to:  o Use licensed local contractors backed by reliable references.   o Demand that contractors carry general liability insurance and worker’s compensation.  • Bogus pleas for post-disaster donations: Unscrupulous solicitors may play on the sympathy for disaster survivors. Disaster aid solicitations may arrive by phone, email, letter or face-to-face visits. Verify legitimate solicitation:  o Ask for the charity’s exact name, street address, phone number, and Web address, then call the charity directly and confirm that the person asking for funds is an employee or volunteer.  o Don’t pay with cash.  o Request a receipt with the charity’s name, street address, phone number and Web address (if applicable).  Anyone with knowledge of fraud, waste or abuse may call the FEMA Disaster Fraud Hotline at 866-720-5721 or report it to the Federal Trade Commission at www.ftccompliantassistant.gov You may also send an email to DHSOIGHotline@dhs.gov

It caps the state and local tax deduction at $10,000, far below the average $23,000 deduction claimed by over 177,000 households in California’s 20th Congressional District each year, and eliminates the mortgage interest deduction claimed by 57% of local homeowners.  I voted against this bill because it will hurt people who live on the Central Coast. The Majority party promised that H.R. 1 would give every American a tax cut. That is not true, and many on the Central Coast could end up paying more in taxes than they do already.  True reform of the American tax code must be a collaborative, bipartisan effort. I hope that the Senate comes together to reject this bill, and creates a bipartisan tax plan that is fair for all Americans.

Adding to my Bipartisan Bills weekly series:  Every week that we are in session, we vote on a number of important pieces of legislation that do not get the attention that they deserve. I understand how people feel about Congress and the partisanship that can occur. However, we are working together to pass many bills.   I have been a bit behind in sharing with you a list of legislation that Congress has passed with strong bipartisan support. Here are some of the bills that we passed this month in the United States House of Representatives:  • The House unanimously passed a resolution on Anti-Harassment House Training, H Res 630 , which requires all employees of the House of Representatives, including all Members, to complete every year an anti-discrimination and anti-harassment workplace training program. • HR 1066, VA Management Alignment Act of 2017, which requires the VA to report to Congress on its organizational structure with recommendations for possible changes to promote effectiveness and accountability. • HR 3122, Veterans Care Financial Protection Act, which requires the VA to warn veterans about financial scam artists. • HR 2123, Veterans E-Health and Telemedicine Support (VETS) Act, to improve the ability of health care professionals to treat veterans through the use of telemedicine. • HR 2601, Veterans Increased Choice for Transplanted Organs and Recovery (VICTOR) Act, to improve the access of veterans to organ transplants. • HR 425, FTO Passport Revocation Act of 2017, which authorizes the State Department to revoke or deny U.S. passports to individuals who become affiliated with foreign terrorist organizations. • HR 3017, Brownfields Enhancement, Economic Redevelopment and Reauthorization Act. The bipartisan bill reauthorizes the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Brownfields program through FY 2022 at the current funding level. The Program provides grants and technical assistance to communities, states, tribes and others to assess, safely clean up and sustainably reuse contaminated properties. • HR 2228, Law Enforcement Mental Health and Wellness Act, which aims to address police officer occupational stress by identifying and incorporating current best practices from other high-stress occupations, and by providing additional resources for law enforcement officers to better manage their stress and associated problems. • HR 2331, Connected Government Act, which requires websites created by the federal government to be mobile friendly, thereby codifying the existing executive branch guidance on federal websites.

The President released his National Security Strategy yesterday. As co-chairs of the Democratic Caucus’ National Security Task Force, here is what I and my colleagues, Rep. Seth Moulton of Massachusetts and Rep. Stephanie Murphy of Florida, have to say about it:  The Trump administration has finally released its legally-required National Security Strategy document, as we called for in June.  As we have witnessed over the past 11 months, the administration’s actions have not aligned with the language of this document.  There is a fundamental disconnect between what the administration says, and what it is actually doing.  For example, the Task Force has urged the administration to use all elements of our national power, pairing a robust military posture with a forceful diplomatic presence.  The document pays lip service to this notion, stating that “diplomacy is indispensable.”  These words ring hollow in light of the fact that the administration has clearly sought to hollow out the State Department and marginalize diplomacy as a national security tool.  Likewise, the Task Force has encouraged the administration to strengthen, not subvert, alliances.  The document states that our “allies and partners are a great strength of the United States.”  Yet, as a result of the President’s actions and rhetoric, our most important partners in Europe and Asia have cause to question the U.S. commitment to our shared security.  It is no surprise that confidence in U.S. leadership has fallen sharply among our closest allies.   In addition, the document says the U.S. will “offer encouragement to those struggling for human dignity in their societies.”  This restates a core American principle, promoted under both Republican and Democratic administrations.  However, this statement rings hollow, given the President’s praise for Russian President Vladmir Putin, Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte, and other authoritarian leaders.  More generally, the Task Force has expressed our dismay that the administration has yet to name or nominate personnel for numerous critical positions at the Departments of Defense and State.  A strategy document—even if sound—is merely words on paper unless the administration has the men and women in place to execute that strategy around the globe.     The credibility and importance of the National Security Strategy rely entirely on the actions of the administration and alignment of these actions with the document's stated goals. To date, these actions have not reflected the goals in the strategy and represent a turn towards an undemocratic, inward-looking approach that stands as a poor excuse for American leadership.

I voted against this tax bill because it would have a negative impact on too many families on the central coast of California and our nation. The bill lowers taxes for the wealthy, while raising taxes on many working and middle-class families. The bill would leave millions without health insurance or with increased premiums. It sets the stage for massive cuts to critical services and entitlements to my constituents and support for our communities. It will add $1.5 trillion to the national debt.   Most disconcerting, the bill caps the state and local tax deduction at $10,000, far below the average $23,000 deduction claimed by over 177,000 households in California’s 20th Congressional District each year. The plan also reduces the limit on the mortgage interest deduction, which will have a detrimental impact on high-cost housing markets in our district.   I believe that we need bipartisan tax reform crafted through an evidenced-based process, with deliberative hearings and input from a wide range of experts. Instead, we were presented today with a partisan bill that was rushed through Congress without sufficient vetting. As a result, we were left with a bill that will not meet the needs of Central Coast middle-class and low-income families, and will only exacerbate the challenges that they and our nation currently face.
